moves.1. f4: This was a very lucky win by me!
moves.1... d5: As far as I can remember, this was the third game between us. I won the first, he won the second and I won this, the third,
moves.2. Nf3: For him, this is relatively normal. He sometimes opens with 1. b3 or 1. b4.
moves.2... g6: I decide to fianchetto my bishop.
moves.5... Nh6: With a plan of f7-f6, Nf7 and e7-e5 in due course, but it is far too slow and white can always hit the black centre with c2-c4. Simply Nf6 is better.
moves.6... Bg4: Now my bishop can't be attacked by h2-h3
moves.11... Bf8: To stop the knight. I wasn't sure of this move at the time, but Fritz thinks it best and gives advantage of 0.44 to black.
moves.12. Bd2: He develops his bishop at last.
moves.13. Bb5: I should have played Bxf3 here, but I changed by mind and played....
moves.13... Qe6 14. Bxc6: Clever move. If I take back with the queen, he has 14. Ne5 Qe6 15. Nxg4. That is not the end of the story - I can then play 15....Ng3 attacking both Rh1 and Ng4, but he has 16. Nf2 meeting 16....Nxh1 with 17. Nxh1 and he has two minor pieces for the rook. I think I can then pick up a pawn, starting with 17....Qg4, but I think in the long run the two minor pieces are better than rook and pawn - besides I am losing my best pieces... Any views dear reader?
moves.16. Nd3: Great move! Now the threat is Nc5 attacking both my queen and threatening mate.
moves.16... Re8: Giving a flight square to my king, and also in some variations the rook action down the e file is crucial.
moves.18... Qd6: Now I am threatening both the rook on h1 and the pawn on f4, due to the pin on the e file by my rook.
moves.19. Kf2: So I have the chance to win the exchange with 19...Nxh1+ 20. Rxh1. But then what? It is hard for me to untangle my pieces. I eventually decided not to take the rook. I was glad when I annotated this, and found that Fritz at first favours 19.....Nxh1 but eventually after thinking for several minutes decides on the move I played....
moves.21. Rac1: He starts ganging up on my queen side weaknesses.
moves.21... h5: Played to prevent his h pawn advancing. Frizt prefers 21...h6. I was hoping for 22. Bb4? Rxf4!+ with advantage, but he is awake to that.
moves.22. Rc5: He starts to double rooks on the c file.
moves.22... f6: I need to break through on the king side.
moves.23... Bd7: So my bishop comes back to protect.
moves.24. Qd3: The queen is about to come in with deadly effect. Fritz now likes 24....Kd8 now with plus 2 to white. What I played is probably the best practical chance.
moves.25... Kd8: Of course my king is a sitting duck if it stays on the queen-side. Plus 4.25 to white now, according to Fritz.
moves.27... Qe7: Fritz prefers Qd7, but it is a bit academic, objectively black is lost.
moves.28. Ba5 gxf4: The best chance. My opponent, not 100% sure that taking on c7 led to a won ending, decided to make everything safe by playing....
moves.29... Rxf4+:
White resigns, it is mate in 2. https://gameknot.com/chess-puzzle.pl?pz=218519
Many thanks for reading. Please rate this annotation on the star system, and leave a comment it two to let me know how I am doing. Until next time dear reader!

players: Ian Jamieson (ECF182) vs. Charles L Higgie (ECF173)
